articles.headline: Democrats Woo Abortion Foes in Push for Health Bill
articles.snippet: House Democratic leaders were exploring a deal that would clinch the votes to pass the legislation, but they faced stiff resistance from lawmakers who support abortion rights.
articles.abstract: House Democratic leaders were exploring a deal that would clinch the votes to pass the legislation, but they faced stiff resistance from lawmakers who support abortion rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democratic leaders late Friday were exploring the possibility of a deal with abortion opponents that would clinch the final votes to pass major health care legislation, but they faced stiff resistance from lawmakers who support abortion rights.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Robert Pear

articles.headline: When Not to Pay Down a Mortgage
articles.snippet: If you’ve locked in a rock-bottom rate, does it still make sense to make extra payments to reduce your mortgage? It depends.
articles.abstract: If you’ve locked in a rock-bottom rate, does it still make sense to make extra payments to reduce your mortgage? It depends.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the Federal Reserve reaffirmed its intention to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, signaling the likelihood that the mortgage rates you can get today are as good as they’re going to be for a long while. Once the Fed stops buying, after all, rates are likely to go up.

articles.headline: In Haiti, Mental Health System Is in Collapse
articles.snippet: Haiti’s earthquake has exposed the inadequacies of its mental health services at the moment they are most needed.
articles.abstract: Haiti’s earthquake has exposed the inadequacies of its mental health services at the moment they are most needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Inside this city’s earthquake-cracked psychiatric hospital, a schizophrenic man lay naked on a concrete floor, caked in dust. Other patients, padlocked in tiny concrete cells, clutched the bars and howled for attention. Feces clotted the gutter outside a ward where urine pooled under metal cots without mattresses.

articles.headline: China’s Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil
articles.snippet: While exports to the United States might rebound this year, in the long run the decline in western demand and the growing importance of China represent a fundamental shift for the oil market.
articles.abstract: While exports to the United States might rebound this year, in the long run the decline in western demand and the growing importance of China represent a fundamental shift for the oil market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Saudi Arabia put the final bolt in its largest oil expansion project ever, opening a new field capable of pumping 1.2 million barrels a day — more than the entire production of Texas. The field, called Khurais, was part of an ambitious $60 billion program to increase the kingdom’s production to meet growing energy needs.

articles.headline: U.S. Plans Spot Tests of Organic Products
articles.snippet: The Department of Agriculture will begin enforcing rules on testing organically grown foods for pesticides, after an audit exposed gaps in the National Organic Program.
articles.abstract: The Department of Agriculture will begin enforcing rules on testing organically grown foods for pesticides, after an audit exposed gaps in the National Organic Program.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Department of Agriculture said on Friday that it would begin enforcing rules requiring the spot testing of organically grown foods for traces of pesticides, after an auditor exposed major gaps in federal oversight of the organic food industry.

articles.headline: Acorn on Brink of Bankruptcy, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The community organizing group has been battered politically from the right and has suffered from mismanagement and a loss of money.
articles.abstract: The community organizing group has been battered politically from the right and has suffered from mismanagement and a loss of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The community organizing group Acorn, battered politically from the right and suffering from mismanagement along with a severe loss of government and other funds, is on the verge of filing for bankruptcy, officials of the group said Friday.

articles.headline: In Bid to Sway Sales, Cameras Track Shoppers
articles.snippet: Retailers say they are using video cameras to watch customers as a way to make shopping in stores more enjoyable, but privacy advocates are skeptical.
articles.abstract: Retailers say they are using video cameras to watch customers as a way to make shopping in stores more enjoyable, but privacy advocates are skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: The curvy mannequin piqued the interest of a couple of lanky teenage boys. Little did they know that as they groped its tight maroon shirt in the clothing store that day, video cameras were rolling.

articles.headline: Consumers Slow to Embrace the Age of Genomics
articles.snippet: One problem is that DNA scanning is often unable to offer meaningful predictions about a person’s risk for a disease.
articles.abstract: One problem is that DNA scanning is often unable to offer meaningful predictions about a person’s risk for a disease.

articles.headline: Rethinking Sex Offender Laws for Youth Texting
articles.snippet: In most states, teenagers who send or receive sexually explicit photographs by cellphone or computer, known as “sexting,” have risked felony child pornography charges.
articles.abstract: In most states, teenagers who send or receive sexually explicit photographs by cellphone or computer, known as “sexting,” have risked felony child pornography charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Iowa, Jorge Canal is on the sex offenders registry because, at age 18, he was convicted of distributing obscene materials to a minor after he sent a picture of his penis by cellphone to a 14-year-old female friend who had requested it.

articles.headline: Does Icahn Still Make Them Tremble?
articles.snippet: Carl C. Icahn likes to be called an activist investor, not a raider. But his latest hostile bid for a company came just last week.
articles.abstract: Carl C. Icahn likes to be called an activist investor, not a raider. But his latest hostile bid for a company came just last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: HE is a billionaire several times over. He has spent the better part of four decades terrorizing corporate chiefs and battling entrenched boards. His name is emblazoned on a stadium on an island in the East River, a laboratory at Princeton, a science center at the Choate Rosemary Hall school in Connecticut and charter schools in the Bronx.

articles.headline: U.S. Turns a Blind Eye to Opium in Afghan Town
articles.snippet: To win over Afghans on former Taliban turf, American commanders are arguing against opium eradication.
articles.abstract: To win over Afghans on former Taliban turf, American commanders are arguing against opium eradication.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The effort to win over Afghans on former Taliban turf in Marja has put American and NATO commanders in the unusual position of arguing against opium eradication, pitting them against some Afghan officials who are pushing to destroy the harvest.

articles.headline: Pools That Need Some Sun
articles.snippet: A lawsuit accuses a group of Wall Street companies of misrepresenting the mortgages underlying $5.4 billion in securities that they sold.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit accuses a group of Wall Street companies of misrepresenting the mortgages underlying $5.4 billion in securities that they sold.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week, the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco sued a throng of Wall Street companies that sold the agency $5.4 billion in residential mortgage-backed securities during the height of the mortgage melee. The suit, filed March 15 in state court in California, seeks the return of the $5.4 billion as well as broader financial damages.

articles.headline: A Supersized Custody Battle Over Marvel Superheroes
articles.snippet: Disney paid $4 billion for Marvel Entertainment and its superheroes, but the heirs of Jack Kirby, who helped create many characters, are now fighting it over copyrights.
articles.abstract: Disney paid $4 billion for Marvel Entertainment and its superheroes, but the heirs of Jack Kirby, who helped create many characters, are now fighting it over copyrights.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Dose of Venom for Candidates Turns Ads Viral
articles.snippet: New campaign attacks in California are using sophisticated, low-cost technology to create nasty ads.
articles.abstract: New campaign attacks in California are using sophisticated, low-cost technology to create nasty ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The virtual image is as mesmerizing as it is creepy. Meg Whitman, the leading Republican candidate for governor of California and the former chief executive of eBay, stands in front of a private jet, her lips peeled back from thick gums, and virtually snorts into the camera, “California, let me take you for a ride.”

articles.headline: Digitally, Location Is Where It’s At
articles.snippet: Location-based services like Foursquare and Gowalla were the talk of the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference in Austin, Tex.
articles.abstract: Location-based services like Foursquare and Gowalla were the talk of the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference in Austin, Tex.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.

articles.headline: Mixing In Some Carbon
articles.snippet: A start-up called Calera says it has found a way to capture carbon dioxide by using it to make cement, but skeptics have doubts.
articles.abstract: A start-up called Calera says it has found a way to capture carbon dioxide by using it to make cement, but skeptics have doubts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSS LANDING, Calif. — It seems like alchemy: a Silicon Valley start-up says it has found a way to capture the carbon dioxide emissions from coal and gas power plants and lock them into cement.

articles.headline: In Health Care Overhaul, Boons for Hospitals and Drug Makers
articles.snippet: With a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s health care system, Congress would be giving the health care industry millions of customers in the next few years.
articles.abstract: With a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s health care system, Congress would be giving the health care industry millions of customers in the next few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s health care system, Congress would be giving the health care industry as many as 32 million additional paying customers in the next few years.

articles.headline: For Consumers, Clarity on Health Care Changes
articles.snippet: The uninsured are the biggest beneficiaries of the bill, which would extend coverage for low-income Americans.
articles.abstract: The uninsured are the biggest beneficiaries of the bill, which would extend coverage for low-income Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers, who spent a year watching Congress scratch and claw over sweeping health care legislation, can now try to figure out what the overhaul would mean for them.

articles.headline: Hoping for Gift From Google? Go Jump in the Lake
articles.snippet: Google’s offer to build a high-speed broadband network in cities has brought out a competitive spirit nationwide.
articles.abstract: Google’s offer to build a high-speed broadband network in cities has brought out a competitive spirit nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mayor of Duluth, Minn., threw himself into the ice-ringed waters of Lake Superior. The mayor of Sarasota, Fla., immersed himself in a tank filled with bonnethead sharks, simply to one-up him. The mayor of Wilmington, N.C., said that he would even jump out of an airplane — with a parachute, of course.

articles.headline: U-2 Spy Plane Evades the Day of Retirement
articles.snippet: The plane that was often at the heart of cold war suspense is now being used to gather intelligence in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The plane that was often at the heart of cold war suspense is now being used to gather intelligence in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U-2 spy plane, the high-flying aircraft that was often at the heart of cold war suspense, is enjoying an encore.

articles.headline: States Look Beyond Borders to Collect Owed Taxes
articles.snippet: Improved techniques for identifying workers from beyond their borders have led states to increase tax enforcement.
articles.abstract: Improved techniques for identifying workers from beyond their borders have led states to increase tax enforcement.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Josh Beckett pitches for the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, New York collects income tax on the portion of his salary that he earned in New York State.

articles.headline: Wall Street Journal Aims to Win Over The New York Times’s Local Audience
articles.snippet: The paper will begin a new section to try to raise circulation and attract high-end advertisers.
articles.abstract: The paper will begin a new section to try to raise circulation and attract high-end advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe newspapers really are dying, as some media analysts have been predicting for decades, but apparently that does not apply to newspaper wars. A doozy is shaping up at the moment between The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times.

articles.headline: Rush Is On to Be First in iPad Apps
articles.snippet: Though the iPad won’t be out until April 3, lots of software developers are looking for the first-out advantage.
articles.abstract: Though the iPad won’t be out until April 3, lots of software developers are looking for the first-out advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can be difficult to write software for a gadget without being able to touch it. But that has not stopped developers from rushing to create applications for the Apple iPad.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Rio Tinto Workers Admit Taking Bribes in China
articles.snippet: Three employees of the  mining giant made stunning confessions at the start of their trial in China.
articles.abstract: Three employees of the  mining giant made stunning confessions at the start of their trial in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s high-profile prosecution of executives of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto took a bizarre turn on Monday, as the executives, once accused of spying, confessed instead to accepting bribes from Chinese steel makers.
